title: Giving small business owners access to health insurance
summary: Led discovery to launch for an SME health insurance proposition, combining research, rapid experimentation and staged demand validation to de-risk the opportunity before full integration.
outcomes: Mapped needs and willingness-to-pay signals via 12 interviews and a 600-customer survey
De-risked positioning through rapid tests (brand vs price, and plain-English vs medical language)
Proved demand progressively: prototype testing → live journey (~2,000 weekly visits) → marketing + PPC (10,000+ weekly visits)
Shipped an integrated SME health insurance offering with Equipsme as the partner

sections.title: Design Challenge
body: Health insurance is notoriously hard to navigate. For small business owners, it’s often framed as a corporate HR benefit—high effort, unclear value, and full of jargon.

Simply Business identified SME health insurance as a growth opportunity, but the bar was high: we needed to prove it was desirable, understandable, and a natural fit within an existing insurance journey—before committing engineering time.

I led the customer experience strategy within a Product Discovery Unit (PM, researcher, analyst, insurance specialist, and myself) to answer one question: should we build this, and if so, what should it be?
identifiedItems: Whether SMEs actually wanted health insurance, and what “good” looked like for them
Which benefits and price points mattered most (and how they talked about them)
Whether customers would trust Simply Business to sell it
bodyEnd: If we couldn’t validate those fundamentals quickly, we’d stop and move on to the next opportunity.

sections.title: Action Taken
body: We started by building a shared understanding of the category and the customer. The goal wasn’t “more research”—it was decision-grade clarity: what to offer, how to communicate it, and which assumptions would sink the proposition if wrong.
identifiedItems: User interviews (12 SME owners already using private health insurance)
A customer survey (600 Simply Business customers) to gauge interest and willingness to pay
Competitive benchmarking across SME offerings to identify gaps and opportunities
bodyEnd: This gave us a grounded view of value drivers (benefits, coverage expectations, and price sensitivity) and a clear signal on language: customers wanted the concept in plain English, anchored in real issues—not insurance terminology.

sections.title: Further Action Taken
sections.leadIn: We pressure-tested the two riskiest assumptions:
identifiedItems: We can offer the right product for small business needs
Customers would trust and buy health insurance through Simply Business
bodyEnd: Rather than debate in the abstract, we turned assumptions into measurable experiments and ran low-fidelity tests before committing engineering effort.

Experiment 1.1 — Brand versus price: when presented with a stronger brand offering fewer benefits versus a lesser-known provider offering better value, participants consistently prioritised tangible value over brand recognition.
Experiment 1.2 — Response to medical language: issue-focused, plain-English options were easier to understand and more compelling than service-led, jargon-heavy descriptions.
Those results sharpened our design principles: prioritise value over brand signalling; use clear, issue-led language; and reduce cognitive load in a complex category.

Experiment 2 — Demand test: we increased fidelity and exposure in stages—clickable prototype testing (15 participants), a live demand test within the quote journey (~2,000 weekly visits), and then a dedicated marketing page supported by PPC (10,000+ weekly visits).
In parallel, we explored how to integrate the product: eligibility checks, where health questions naturally fit, and how to present it as an intuitive add-on without disrupting core purchase flows.
After selecting Equipsme as the partner, we ran ads offering free health insurance for a limited time—building shared confidence while engineering work ramped up.

sections.title: Results
body: By the time we reached build decisions, the conversation had shifted from “should we?” to “what’s the most focused version we can ship with confidence?”
We had clear evidence on what customers valued, how to communicate it, and how demand scaled as we moved from prototypes to real traffic.
That allowed the team to integrate health insurance into the existing journey with a crisp proposition, minimal cognitive load, and a measured rollout plan.
